title: News Blizzard
location: A bustling newsroom filled with the hum of activity. Multiple screens display various news channels, each flickering with urgent updates. The room is a mix of modern technology and chaotic energy, with reporters and producers rushing about.
time: Evening, during a live news broadcast. The atmosphere is tense and electric, with the weight of breaking news hanging in the air.
scene_description: The screen flickers with static before cutting to a rapid-fire montage of news reports from around the world. The camera zooms in on the News Anchor, who sits behind a sleek desk, papers scattered in front of them. The Producer stands nearby, headset on, barking orders to the crew. A Reporter rushes in, breathless, clutching a tablet with the latest updates.

dialogue.speaker: Producer
dialogue.line: We're live in 5, everyone get ready!

dialogue.speaker: News Anchor
dialogue.line: Good evening, we interrupt your regular programming to bring you breaking news from around the world.

dialogue.speaker: Reporter
dialogue.line: Just got an update from our correspondent in Kabul.

dialogue.speaker: News Anchor
dialogue.line: Thank you. We're receiving reports of escalating tensions in Afghanistan...

thoughts.line: This is it. The moment we've been preparing for. I need to stay calm and deliver the news accurately.
Everything needs to run smoothly. The world is watching.

actions.action: Adjusts their headset, eyes scanning the monitors, hands gesturing to the crew.
Hands the tablet to the News Anchor, stepping back to watch the broadcast.
Takes a deep breath, straightens their posture, and looks directly into the camera.

outcome: The News Anchor delivers the breaking news with professionalism, the Producer ensures the broadcast runs smoothly, and the Reporter stands by, ready to provide more updates as they come in. The newsroom continues to buzz with activity as the world tunes in to the latest developments.

title: Ambush Aftermath
location: A dusty, remote dirt road lined with sparse vegetation and the wreckage of a military jeep, smoke billowing from its hood. The sound of distant gunfire echoes through the air.
time: Early evening, the sun beginning to set, casting long, dramatic shadows across the chaotic scene.
scene_description: The scene is chaotic, with the camera shaking and capturing accidental footage. A dirt road stretches out, with a crashed jeep belching smoke. Gunfire rings out sporadically, and soldiers are seen running in various directions, some trying to take cover, others attempting to assist their fallen comrades. The air is thick with tension and the acrid smell of smoke and gunpowder.

dialogue.speaker: ITN Newsreader
dialogue.line: British troops involved in a...

dialogue.speaker: Sky Newsreader
dialogue.line: ...four dead, two injured in a sudden ambush today.

dialogue.speaker: Man (Soldier)
dialogue.line: Watson!!

dialogue.speaker: BBC Newsreader
dialogue.line: ...increased hostilities over the last few weeks have resulted in multiple casualties.

dialogue.speaker: Sky Newsreader
dialogue.line: ...until relatives have been informed, names are being withheld.

dialogue.speaker: Man (Soldier)
dialogue.line: Watson!! Where are you?!

thoughts.line: I need to find Watson. He was right next to me when the jeep flipped. Please, let him be okay.
I can't move my leg. The pain is unbearable. I hope someone finds me soon.

actions.action: Frantically searches through the wreckage and the surrounding area, calling out for Watson.
Some are returning fire, others are administering first aid to the injured, and a few are trying to secure the perimeter.

outcome: The scene fades out with the Man (Soldier) still searching for Watson, the fate of the soldiers left uncertain as the newsreaders continue to report on the escalating situation.

title: Awakening to a New Reality

location.INT. JOHN\u2019S BEDSIT: A small, sparsely furnished room with a single bed, a desk, and a few neatly folded clothes. The walls are bare, and the atmosphere is somber and quiet.
location.INT. THERAPIST\u2019S CONSULTING ROOM: A professional yet inviting space with comfortable chairs, a desk, and shelves filled with books. Soft lighting creates a calming ambiance.

time.NIGHT: The dead of night, with only the faint glow of streetlights filtering through the window.
time.DAY: Early morning, as the first light of dawn begins to illuminate the room.

scene_description: John Watson, a war veteran, wakes up from a nightmare, his mind still haunted by the horrors of war. He struggles to adjust to civilian life, seeking solace in writing a blog. His therapist, Ella, encourages him to open up and share his experiences, but John remains guarded and reluctant.

dialogue.speaker: ITN Newsreader (V.O.)
dialogue.line: Two more have died in the worst outbreak of violence...

dialogue.speaker: SKY Newsreader (V.O.)
dialogue.line: ...said his thoughts were with the victims' families...

dialogue.speaker: Man (V.O.)
dialogue.line: Watson!!

dialogue.speaker: Ella (V.O.)
dialogue.line: How’s your blog going?

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: Oh, fine. Good. Very good.

dialogue.speaker: Ella
dialogue.line: You haven’t written a word, have you?

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: You just wrote 'still has trust issues'.

dialogue.speaker: Ella
dialogue.line: And you read my writing upside down. See what I mean?

dialogue.speaker: Ella
dialogue.line: John, you’re a soldier. It’s going to take you a while to adjust to civilian life - writing a blog about everything that happens to you, will honestly help you. Trust me.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: Nothing happens to me.

thoughts.line: The cane... a constant reminder of my limitations. I hate it.
The gun... a part of my past I can’t escape. But I have to move on.
Writing this blog feels like exposing my soul. I’m not sure I’m ready for that.

actions.action: Wakes up suddenly, sweating and disoriented.
Sits up in bed, taking deep breaths to calm himself.
Looks around the room, taking in the sparse surroundings.
Frowns at the sight of his walking cane, feeling a mix of resentment and acceptance.
Sets down a coffee cup on the desk and opens a drawer to retrieve his laptop, revealing a hidden gun.
Stares at the gun for a moment, then firmly closes the drawer.
Opens his laptop to a blog page, the cursor blinking expectantly.
Sits stiffly in the therapist’s office, feeling out of place and slightly embarrassed.
Makes a note on her notepad, observing John’s reactions.

emotions.John: Conflicted, guarded, and struggling with his past.
emotions.Ella: Patient, understanding, and determined to help John.

outcome: John remains guarded and reluctant to open up, but Ella’s persistence and understanding offer a glimmer of hope that he might eventually find a way to cope with his past and adjust to civilian life.

title: A Fateful Morning at Waterloo Station
location: A bustling London railway station, Waterloo, filled with the hum of commuters, the scent of coffee and newspapers, and the occasional whistle of trains.
time: March 12th, mid-morning, under a typical London grey sky.
scene_description: The camera pans over the crowded railway station, zooming in on Sir Jeffrey Patterson, a middle-aged man in a well-tailored suit, looking slightly out of place among the rush-hour commuters. He is on his mobile phone, his expression a mix of frustration and urgency.

dialogue.speaker: Jeffrey
dialogue.line: Car! There’s no ruddy car!

dialogue.speaker: Helen
dialogue.line: He went to Waterloo, sorry. Just get a cab.

dialogue.speaker: Jeffrey
dialogue.line: I never get cabs!

dialogue.speaker: Helen
dialogue.line: I love you.

dialogue.speaker: Jeffrey
dialogue.line: When?

dialogue.speaker: Helen
dialogue.line: Get a cab.

thoughts.line: Why can’t anything go right today? I hate being stranded like this.
He’s so stubborn, but I can’t help but smile at his determination.

actions.action: Looks around for the TAXI sign, starts heading away, a hint of determination in his stride.
Smiles, glances around the office, ensuring no one is within earshot before speaking softly into the phone.

outcome: Jeffrey, despite his initial reluctance, decides to take a cab, buoyed by Helen’s words of love and support. The scene fades to black, hinting at the ominous events to come.

title: Conversation on the Roof
location: The flat roof of Scotland Yard, offering a panoramic view of London's skyline. The roof is accessible through a rusty service door, surrounded by ventilation ducts and antennas.
time: A breezy day, with the sun occasionally hidden behind scattered clouds. The air is filled with the distant hum of the city below.
scene_description: Lestrade steps onto the roof, the service door creaking shut behind him. He cups his hands around a cigarette, trying to light it in the breeze. He knows he's not alone; Sherlock is already here, his silhouette standing starkly against the city backdrop, lost in thought.

dialogue.speaker: Lestrade
dialogue.line: Trying to give these up, actually. I was thinking of a pipe. What do pipes do for you cigarettes don’t?

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: Cancer of the jaw.

dialogue.speaker: Lestrade
dialogue.line: Okay. What am I getting wrong this time?

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: No notes. No prior sign. Each of them in a strange location that means nothing to them where they’ve never gone before... That’s not how I’d kill myself.

dialogue.speaker: Lestrade
dialogue.line: ... So. How are you doing these days?

thoughts.line: Always the dramatics with Sherlock. But he's right, the suicides don't add up.
The city's veins are pulsing with secrets. These deaths, they're not right. Something's connecting them, something we're not seeing.

actions.action: Steps through the service door, tries to light a cigarette, looks around the roof, glances uneasily at Sherlock standing near the edge.
Stands at the edge of the roof, looking out over London, his back turned to Lestrade.

emotions.Lestrade: A mix of resignation and curiosity, with a hint of concern for Sherlock's well-being.
emotions.Sherlock: Introspective, analytical, slightly melancholic, but focused on the case at hand.

outcome: Lestrade, despite his initial casual demeanor, shows genuine concern for Sherlock's well-being. Sherlock, engrossed in the peculiarities of the recent suicides, hints at a deeper mystery brewing in the city. The scene resolves with an unspoken agreement between the two men to delve further into the case, their professional bond strengthening.

title: Unexpected Reunion
location: A bustling park filled with people strolling, walking their dogs, and jogging. The sun is shining, and the atmosphere is lively and vibrant.
time: A bright and clear day, with the sun high in the sky, indicating mid-afternoon.
scene_description: John Watson, limping with the aid of a walking stick, moves determinedly through the park. His face is set in a grim expression, reflecting his inner turmoil and physical pain. The park is alive with activity, but John seems oblivious to his surroundings, focused solely on his journey.

dialogue.speaker: Mike
dialogue.line: John!

dialogue.speaker: Mike
dialogue.line: John Watson!

dialogue.speaker: Mike
dialogue.line: Stamford - Mike Stamford, we were at Barts together.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: Yes. Sorry, yes, Mike, hello!

dialogue.speaker: Mike
dialogue.line: Yes, I know, I got fat. I heard you were abroad somewhere getting shot at. What happened?

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: I got shot.

thoughts.line: Just keep moving. One step at a time. Don't let the pain stop you.
Is that really John Watson? He looks like he's been through hell.

actions.action: Hobbles along with a walking stick, his limping leg evident.
Grabs John's hand and pumps it enthusiastically, a broad smile on his face.

emotions.John: Determined, grim, and slightly uncomfortable with the unexpected encounter.
emotions.Mike: Excited, friendly, and a bit nostalgic about their past.

outcome: John and Mike reconnect after years, with Mike's friendly demeanor contrasting sharply with John's somber mood. The scene ends with a sense of rekindled friendship and a hint of the challenges John has faced.

title: Reunion at the Park
location: A bustling park on a sunny day. The Criterion Cappuccino Stand is nearby, with people milling about, enjoying their drinks. Birds chirp, and children play in the distance.
time: Mid-morning, the sun is high, casting a warm glow over the park. The atmosphere is relaxed and cheerful.
scene_description: Mike and John, old friends, walk away from the Cappuccino stand, coffees in hand. John's limp is noticeable, and Mike can't help but glance at the cane John is using.

dialogue.speaker: Mike
dialogue.line: You okay?

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: Just my leg.

dialogue.speaker: Mike
dialogue.line: Bad, is it?

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: My therapist thinks it’s psychosomatic.

dialogue.speaker: Mike
dialogue.line: What do you think?

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: I think I got shot.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: You’re still at Barts then?

dialogue.speaker: Mike
dialogue.line: Teaching now - bright young things, like we used to be. God, I hate them. What about you? Staying in town till you get yourself sorted?

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: Can’t afford London on an army pension.

dialogue.speaker: Mike
dialogue.line: And you couldn’t bear to be anywhere else. Not the John Watson I know!

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: I’m not the John Watson you --

dialogue.speaker: Mike
dialogue.line: Couldn’t Harry help?

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: Yeah, that’s going to happen.

dialogue.speaker: Mike
dialogue.line: Well I don’t know - get a flatshare or something?

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: Who’d want me for a flatmate?

thoughts.line: I don’t want to get into all this. It’s too painful to discuss.
John looks tired, worn down. I wish there was more I could do to help.

actions.line: Raises his Cappuccino for a sip, but his hand is shaking badly. He sets it down again, trying to hide his discomfort.
Notices John’s shaking hand and feels a pang of concern.

outcome: The conversation reveals John's struggles with his injury and financial situation, highlighting the emotional strain he's under. Mike's concern is evident, but John remains guarded, unwilling to delve deeper into his problems.

title: Jennifer's Journey and the Mystery at Lauriston Gardens

location.EXT. RAILWAY STATION: A bustling railway station with a long queue at the taxi rank. The sound of trains and people chattering fills the air.
location.INT. LAURISTON GARDENS: A dimly lit, abandoned apartment with bare floorboards and a sense of eerie silence.

time.EXT. RAILWAY STATION: A bright, sunny day with clear skies.
time.INT. LAURISTON GARDENS: Later that day, with a slightly gloomy atmosphere.

scene_description.EXT. RAILWAY STATION: Jennifer Wilson stands in the queue, dressed entirely in pink, including a pink-covered iPhone. She looks determined yet slightly anxious, trying to reassure someone on the phone.
scene_description.INT. LAURISTON GARDENS: A mysterious pill bottle stands alone on the bare floorboards. The room is quiet, and the atmosphere is tense.

dialogue.speaker: Jennifer Wilson
dialogue.line: One hour, I’ll be there. Honestly, I’ll be there. You get the drinks in.

thoughts.line: I hope I can make it on time. I don't want to let them down.

actions.action: Shuffles forward in the queue, holding her pink-covered iPhone tightly.
A pink-fingernailed hand reaches into shot, taking the pill bottle.

outcome: Jennifer's determination to reach her destination is highlighted as the scene fades to black. The mystery deepens as a pink-fingernailed hand reaches for the pill bottle in the abandoned apartment, leaving the audience in suspense.

title: First Encounter at Baker Street
location: The iconic Baker Street in London, with its bustling energy and historic charm. The exterior of 221B Baker Street is quintessentially Victorian, while the interior is a chaotic mix of modern technology and antiquated curiosities.
time: A crisp, sunny afternoon. The kind of day that makes London feel alive and full of possibilities.
scene_description: The scene opens with a close-up of the Baker Street sign, panning to the famous 221B door. John Watson, a man with a military bearing and a hint of weariness, is about to ring the doorbell. Sherlock Holmes, eccentric and brilliant, emerges from a cab, paying the driver with a distracted air.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Hi.

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: Mr. Holmes!

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Sherlock, please.

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: Prime spot. Got to be expensive.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Mrs. Hudson, the landlady. She’s giving me a special deal. Owes me a favour - few years ago, her husband got himself sentenced to death in Florida. I was able to help out.

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: You stopped her husband being executed.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Oh, no. I ensured it.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs. Hudson
dialogue.line: Sherlock!

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: Well! This could be very nice. Very nice indeed.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Yes, I think so. My thoughts exactly.

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: Soon as we get all this rubbish cleaned out.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: So I went ahead and moved in.

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: So, this is all --

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Obviously I can straighten things up a bit.

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: That’s a skull.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Friend of mine. Well I say friend...

dialogue.speaker: Mrs. Hudson
dialogue.line: What do you think, Dr. Watson - there’s another bedroom upstairs. If you’ll be needing two bedrooms...

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: Well of course we’ll be needing two.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs. Hudson
dialogue.line: Oh don’t you worry, all sorts round here. Mrs. Turner next door’s got married ones. Oh, Sherlock, the mess you’ve made.

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: Looked you up on the Internet last night.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Anything interesting?

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: Found your website - The Science of Deduction.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: What did you think?

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: You said you could identify a software designer by his tie, and an airline pilot by his left thumb.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Yes. And I can read your military career in your face and your leg, and the drinking habits of your brother in your mobile phone.

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: How?

dialogue.speaker: Mrs. Hudson
dialogue.line: What about these suicides, then, Sherlock? Thought that would be right up your street. Three of them, exactly the same. That’s a bit funny, isn’t it?

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Four. There’s been a fourth. And there’s something different this time.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs. Hudson
dialogue.line: A fourth? How do you know?

dialogue.speaker: DI Lestrade
dialogue.line: Brixton. Lauriston Gardens.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: What’s different about this one. You wouldn’t have come to get me, if there wasn’t something new.

dialogue.speaker: DI Lestrade
dialogue.line: You know how they never leave notes? This one did. Will you come?

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Who’s on Forensics?

dialogue.speaker: DI Lestrade
dialogue.line: Anderson.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Anderson won’t work with me.

dialogue.speaker: DI Lestrade
dialogue.line: He won’t be your assistant.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: But I need an assistant.

dialogue.speaker: DI Lestrade
dialogue.line: Will you come?

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Not in a police car. I’ll be right behind you.

dialogue.speaker: DI Lestrade
dialogue.line: Thankyou!

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Brilliant!

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: And I thought it was going to be a boring evening. Serial suicides, and now a note - oh, it’s Christmas!

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Mrs. Hudson, I’ll be late - might need some food.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs. Hudson
dialogue.line: I’m your landlady, dear, not your housekeeper.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Something cold is fine. John make yourself at home - have a cuppa! Don’t wait up!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs. Hudson
dialogue.line: Oh, look at him, dashing about? My husband was just the same.

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: Damn my leg!

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: I’m sorry, I’m so sorry, it’s just sometimes ... bloody thing.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs. Hudson
dialogue.line: I understand, dear. I’ve got a hip.

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: A cup of tea would be lovely, thank you.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs. Hudson
dialogue.line: Just this once, dear - I’m not your housekeeper.

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: Couple of biscuits too, if you’ve got them.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs. Hudson
dialogue.line: Not your housekeeper.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: You’re a doctor.

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: Yes.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: In fact, you’re an army doctor.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Any good?

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: Very good.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Seen a lot of injuries then. Violent deaths?

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: Well, yes.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Bit of trouble too, I bet.

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: Of course, yes. Enough for a lifetime. Far too much.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Want to see some more?

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: Oh, God, yes!

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Get your coat.

dialogue.speaker: John Watson
dialogue.line: Sorry, Mrs. Hudson, I’ll skip the cuppa - off out.

dialogue.speaker: Mrs. Hudson
dialogue.line: Both of you?

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Impossible suicides - four of them. No point in sitting at home when there’s finally something fun going on!

dialogue.speaker: Mrs. Hudson
dialogue.line: Look at you, all happy. It’s not decent.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock Holmes
dialogue.line: Who cares about decent. The game, Mrs. Hudson, is on!

thoughts.line: Who is this guy? He’s eccentric, brilliant, and completely unpredictable.
John Watson - a man of action, a doctor with a military past. He could be useful.
These two are going to be quite the pair. I can already tell this is going to be interesting.

actions.action: Rings the doorbell at 221B Baker Street.
Pays the cab driver and approaches John Watson.
Opens the door and greets Sherlock Holmes with a joyous hug.
Enters the chaotic sitting room, looking around in amazement.
Busies himself at his desk, stuffing things into his pockets.
Bustles about, straightening up the room.
Enters the room, feet thumping on the stairs.
Leaps over the sofa and dashes for the door.
Hesitates for a second, then dashes after Sherlock Holmes.
Pokes her head out of the door at the foot of the stairs.

emotions.John Watson: Curious, slightly bemused, and increasingly excited.
emotions.Sherlock Holmes: Energetic, focused, and thrilled by the prospect of a new case.
emotions.Mrs. Hudson: Joyous, slightly exasperated, and faintly knowing.
emotions.DI Lestrade: Urgent, slightly relieved to have Sherlock’s help.

outcome: The scene resolves with Sherlock Holmes and John Watson dashing out of 221B Baker Street, eager to investigate the mysterious suicides. Mrs. Hudson watches them go, slightly bemused but understanding that something exciting is afoot.

title: First Encounter and the Ride to the Crime Scene
location: The iconic Baker Street in London, with its bustling energy and historic charm. The interior of a speeding taxi, with the city lights flashing by.
time: A bright, energetic day transitioning into a bustling night in the heart of London.
scene_description: Sherlock Holmes and Dr. John Watson burst out of the door at Baker Street for the first time, marking an iconic moment. Sherlock hurriedly hails a taxi, and they speed through the streets of London. Inside the taxi, Sherlock's mind is racing as he answers Watson's questions with his signature deductive brilliance, revealing insights into Watson's past and his own unique profession.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: Taxi!

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: Okay, you’ve got questions!

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: Where are we going?

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: Crime scene, next.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: Who are you? What do you do?

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: What do you think?

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: I’d say you were a private detective but --

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: But?

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: The police don’t go to private detectives.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: I’m a consulting detective. Only one in the world, I invented the job.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: What does that mean?

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: It means when the police are out of their depth - which is always - they consult me.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: But the police don’t consult --

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: Amateurs.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: When I first met you yesterday I said, Afghanistan or Iraq? You seemed surprised.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: How did you know?

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: I didn’t know. I saw.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: Tanned face -- but no tan above the wrists. You’ve been abroad but not sunbathing.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: Your haircut and the way you hold yourself says military - but your conversation as you entered the room -- says you trained at Barts. So - army doctor. Obvious!

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: Your limp is really bad when you walk, but you don’t ask for a chair when you stand, like you’ve forgotten about it - so it’s at least partly psychosomatic. That says the circumstances of the original injury were traumatising - wounded in action then.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: Wounded in action, a suntan. Afghanistan or Iraq?

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: You said I had a therapist.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: You’ve got psychosomatic limp, of course you’ve got a therapist. Then there’s your brother --

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: Your phone. Expensive, email enabled, mp3 player - you’re looking for a flatshare, you wouldn’t waste money on this. It’s a gift then.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: Scratches - not just one, but many over time. Been in the same pocket as keys and coins. The man in front of me wouldn’t treat his one luxury item like this, so there’s been a previous owner. Next bit’s easy - you know it already.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: The engraving.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: Harry Watson - clearly a family member who’s given you his old phone. Not your father - this is a young man’s gadget. Could be a cousin, but you’re a war hero who can’t find a place to live - unlikely you’ve got an extended family, certainly not one you’re close to. So - brother it is.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: Now Clara, who’s Clara - three kisses says it’s a romantic attachment, the expense of the phone says wife not girlfriend. She must have given it to him recently, this model’s only six months old. It’s a marriage in trouble then - six months on he’s just given it away. If she’d left him, he’d probably have kept the phone - people do, sentiment - but no, he wanted rid of it: he left her. He gave the phone to you - that says he wants you to stay in touch.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: You’re looking for cheap accommodation, but you’re not going to your brother for help - that says you’ve got problems with him. Maybe you liked his wife, maybe you don’t like his drinking --

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: How can you possibly know about the drinking?

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: Shot in the dark - good one though. The power connection. Tiny little scuff marks all round it - he plugs it in every night to recharge, but his hands are shaking. Never see those marks on a sober man’s phone, never see a drunk’s without them.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: There you go, you see? You were right.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: I was right? Right about what?

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: The police don’t consult amateurs.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: That was ... amazing.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: Do you think so?

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: Well, of course it was. It was extraordinary. Quite extraordinary.

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: That’s not what people usually say.

dialogue.speaker: John
dialogue.line: What do they usually say?

dialogue.speaker: Sherlock
dialogue.line: Piss off.

thoughts.line: This man is intriguing. His past is a puzzle, and I love puzzles.
Who is this man? He’s unlike anyone I’ve ever met.

actions.action: Hails a taxi and jumps in, eager to get to the crime scene.
Follows Sherlock into the taxi, trying to keep up with his rapid deductions.
Flicks through items on his PDA, his mind racing with deductions.
Listens intently, a mix of awe and confusion on his face.
Tosses John’s phone back to him, having made his point.
Stares at Sherlock, genuinely impressed and a bit overwhelmed.

emotions.Sherlock: Excited, focused, slightly pleased by John’s reaction.

outcome: Sherlock impresses John with his deductive skills, setting the stage for their future partnership. The taxi ride ends with John's newfound respect for Sherlock's abilities, despite his unorthodox methods.
